comments:
This course is designed to prepare Master of Environmental Studies students to
undertake their Capstone exercises. In this course, how to identify an appropriate research
project, how to design a research plan, and how to prepare a detailed proposal are
discussed. Each student should enter the course with a preliminary research plan and
should have identified an advisor. By the end of the course, each student is expected to
have a completed Capstone proposal that has been reviewed and approved by his/her
advisor.
Students in this course generally agreed that they did not learn much, saying the
course was “not very useful.” Several found the course to be “a bit repetitive” and
“better suited for people unfamiliar with the research process.” However, most students
agreed that it was helpful for “staying on track to complete a capstone proposal.” Many
students commented that there was little student interaction, which they thought would
have made the course more helpful.
Not many students reported directly on the professor for this course. Those who
did called Professor Kulik an “excellent instructor,” “very approachable,” and “a nice
man.” However, a couple of students noted that Professor Kulik repeatedly ended class
very early. One student remarked that Professor Kulik, “cancelled classes,… consistently
started late, dismissed class early and did not provide any insight into project ideas with
his conversation or homework submissions.”
Generally, students did not remark on the difficulty of the course. One student
remarked that the “readings weren’t necessary” and that the professor “never referred to”
the purchased book in class.
